climbs.name: Vote for Pedro
climbs.fa: Brian Cabe and Dale Ralphs October 2005

content.description: A stiff slabby start leads to easier fun moves above.
Just left of the tunnel, climb the nice slabby face past bolts and a couple of gear placments to a chain anchor.

A great line that starts off with some intricate moves on superb stone with interesting feature. The crux is getting past the third bolt by negotiating a small overlap. Delicate friction and edging while deciphering the unique holds will get you through it. The route lets off for a bit, only to re-engage you for the last thirty feet on pronounced smears. The rock is course textured yet surprisingly solid and non-gritty.
content.protection: Bolts to a two-bolt chain anchor. A small cam could prove helpful past the crux.
content.location: This route starts underneath the giant boulder that leans against "The Taco" and is just to the right of "Taco Time".

content.description: Fun, mostly bolted route up the center of the slab.
content.protection: A few bolts and one yellow TCU or equal in the horizontal about halfway up.  Chain anchor.

content.description: Start like the name implies in a fun hand craft in a dihedral at the base of the South ridge. Jam up the corner until you can reach the large horn and pull onto the slab of the ridge line.  A bit run out on the ridge but a bolt can be clipped about mid-way. Cruise up the ridge line to the top and use anchors for "Mole' Plablano" on the West Side.
content.protection: Selection of cams from .5 to 3in. 1 draw for the bolt.
content.location: South Ridge, Rap from anchors on the west side.

content.description: Crux is start or slabby moves left after 4th or so bolt
content.location: On outside of giant boulder leaning against west side of Taco

climbs.name: Nacho Libre
climbs.fa: Brian Cabe and Patty Black 13 May 2006

content.description: Chimney up the leaning block, clip one bolt in the chimney, place a cam where the chimney pinches off. Clip two more on your way to the top.  Traverse to the right and use "Vote for Pedro" anchors.
content.protection: 3 bolts and a piece where the chmney closes off.
content.location: Just to the right of the cave.

climbs.name: Molé Poblano
climbs.fa: Brian Cabe and Dottie Cross Oct 2005

content.description: Scramble ontop of large detached flake to reach first bolt.  Continue to the top clipping a few more bolts to a chain anchor.
content.location: Furthest right route on the slab. Rap route with one 60m rope.

content.description:
Start on the slightly overhanging face on the hunk of rock that leans against the Taco.

Traverse up, sling a less than inspiring horn, then up to the arete to the right, where a pocket takes a large (#4 camalot) cam.  Up the featured face to top of the leaning rock.

Route can be continued at a fairly low grade to the summit ridge of the Taco.  Descend from there.

Or...use the fixed anchor at the top of the leaning hunk of rock on "Not a Taco".

Unknown how much of this route shares with the sport route "Not a Taco".  As such, presented here for historical perspective.
content.protection: Not much was present for the FA as there was no bolts on the face or a fixed anchor.
content.location:
Just past the little cave formed by the leaning rock hunk, climb starts on the face just out of the cave on the left as the cave is exited.

Start on the slightly overhanging route and finish up the west facing featured face.

content.description:
A fun jaunt up a variety of features.

Start on the slab, a little steep bit on jugs, then another slab, to the steeper featured face.

Route seems to go with a single 60m rope but be darn careful with any top roping.  Tie a knot in the end!!!

Bueno!
content.protection: Bolted sports route.  Around a dozen quickdraws to a bolted anchor.
content.location:
Route is located just to the right of the obvious corner crack Bandito.

Rappel route.

climbs.name: Horchata
climbs.fa: Brian Cabe and Dottie Cross Oct 2005

content.description: Variation to "Mole' Problano". After the third bot on "Mole'" move right to the thin crack and continue to same anchors.
content.protection: Draws and a selection of small nuts and cams.

content.description:
A fun jaunt in a more secluded location on the Taco.

A gritty start in/near a corner with a bolt a ways off the deck leads to a low angle slab to a steep finish.

Take care getting to the first bolt.  Low angle but a tumble a ways off the ground might not be fun.

Low angle slab with a couple of bolts.  Steeper finish on fun edges to a change in character to pure friction below the anchor.

Take care on the steeper bit...rock is good, edges are crispy, but, with that much rope out a short fall could land you on the low angle slab.

Don't lower off this route with a 60m rope!  Tie a knot in the blunt end!  Route can be CAREFULLY rappelled with a 60m rope with no extra, but, since the route wanders a bit, lowering would be not recommended.
content.protection: 7 or 8 lead bolts to a two bolt/chain anchor.
content.location:
Located over the large block to the north of La Cruz and Holy Frijoles (on the right side of the east face).

There are currently two routes on the far right end of the East Face of the Taco:  Conejito on the left, and No Mas (no anchor too apparently) on the right.

Approach by aiming for the far right side of the face and take the small social trail to the low angle slabs below the route.

content.description: Fun RF flaring finger to hand crack/flake system on great rock.  The first half is the hardest then eases up a bit.  Takes gear great.  The crack ends about 40 feet from the summit and the run out is a bit heady to the anchors on the west side.  Not hard climbing (5.5 or so) but watch the rope drag.
content.protection: Double set of camalots and a set of nuts a few runners as well. Use " Mole' Problano's" anchors on the west side. Rap with 1 rope.
content.location: The obvious crack on the East side.
